content: Hi @T-compiler/meeting! Please leave a :wave: to indicate you're here.
This morning we're going to be discussing the memshrink sprint.
I'll be working off the template @pnkfelix left https://hackmd.io/n_G11TzET1CjaTeouQ6CsQ
Let's give a few minutes for
Announcements:
Ok, no announcements then!
I think I'd like to start by talking about what we think went well during the sprint
One thing in particular that I think was very helpful to me was the video/voice chat room @oli started.
I know a number of people joined and we had some interesting conversations there.
I would like for us to do that again in the next sprint
Does anyone else feel similarly?
I know it usually hit my lunch times which was unfortunate, though I later got the impression it was running for longer too
Ah, that's a good point.
Perhaps next time it would be good to try to coordinate that a bit more.
I believe @oli was sitting on the call for a few hours at a time just in case others showed up.
A kickoff call the first day in a prescheduled time might work a bit better.
ugh I’m so sorry for missing the beginning of this
(ironically I was distracted talking to niko)
I too think @oli ’s calls were one of the highlights
I suspect two distinct prescheduled times, in order to accomodate varied time zones, might be an improvement
(maybe 4 hours apart or something? Just spitballing)
Yeah, I think we should try to incorporate that into the schedule ahead of time. Maybe we can try to find a few different times that work for various people.
(I was also wondering if it would be a more general thing we should consider. Not connected to the sprints, just a social thing)
(but I think orienting it around the sprints helps give it direction)

pnkfelix said:

(ironically I was distracted talking to niko)

sorry :)
The part of MS I'm in actually has a few different weekly teams calls for social hours since everyone is working remotely.
We probably should do a call to celebrate after each release

Wesley Wiser said:

The part of MS I'm in actually has a few different weekly teams calls for social hours since everyone is working remotely.

And my team does too!
So perhaps it would be fun to do occasionally :smile:
Overall I think we got some good brainstorming
I myself didn’t make progress on something I had hoped to do, which was to gather data on how strongly correlated the estimated MIR sizes are with actual code sizes
but still think it would be good to work on
I know that @oli spent some time doing targetted optimizations of the internal representations for some things
max-rss was reduced in some of our perf tests by boxing uncommon enum cases
Yeah, I spent most of the week on an idea that didn't quite pan out but I did get some pretty interesting data as a result.
That was not entirely satisfying but still productive I think.

oli said:

max-rss was reduced in some of our perf tests by boxing uncommon enum cases

link? Which perf tests did it affect?

Wesley Wiser said:

Yeah, I spent most of the week on an idea that didn't quite pan out but I did get some pretty interesting data as a result.

the codegen-unit splitting, right?
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/82727#issuecomment-790817916

@Santiago Pastorino ran a few experiments on MIR opts to see if it made sense to turn any on just in release mode, but it doesn't look like that is useful yet. Likely blocked on mir inlining :upside_down:

pnkfelix said:

Wesley Wiser said:

Yeah, I spent most of the week on an idea that didn't quite pan out but I did get some pretty interesting data as a result.

the codegen-unit splitting, right?

Yeah. https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/276895-t-compiler.2Fshrinkmem-sprint/topic/cgu.20sizes for that work.

Likely blocked on mir inlining

soon :fingers_crossed:
I think the main thing I “accomplished” was the addition of build.print_step_rusage to config.toml (PR #82532)
and @rylev generalized that to Windows in PR #82754, which is still in flight
but I doubt its being used much in practice yet

@rylev and I also spent a bunch of time learning the Windows Performance Analysis tool and we documented our learnings in the rustc-dev guide. https://rustc-dev-guide.rust-lang.org/profiling/wpa_profiling.html
BTW, I would encourage others to document anything they learned about memory profiling there as well. It would be great not to lose this knowledge now that the sprint is over.
hey @nikomatsakis , do you know if your perf-focus tool is still of use?
(I suppose that isn’t going to answer Q’s about memory usage. At least, not yet.)
anyway I think we can invest more effort in documenting the tools to use
I’m thriled to see that WPA documentation. Especially since it sets a bar for the Linux side to meet.
We should totally gamify this.
So, okay, any other wins or “what worked” to report? I think I’m ready to move on to “what didn’t work"
sorry, I'm just showing up, but yeah the calls that @oli started were a highlight to me
having a sense of working together and with others is IMO something that we should keep trying to do in these sprints, otherwise what would be special about these sprints?
One personal miss: I personally had promised to deliver info on how to use dhat. (That was in part because I discovered it’s overhead was too high for our use-case, I think.)
but more generally I suspect you all would agree that we didn’t have enough of a plan going into the sprint

another thing that could have worked is making some plans on things to do and then using the calls as a daily meeting to report what each one is working on, see if people is blocked on something and have the time to ask for help or stuff like that
ouch weirly phrased, I'm not saying we didn't plan :)
that’s okay; I said it.
but there was a document with things to do
what I was trying to say is that calls more oriented like daily meetings could be useful
do you mean this doc, @Santiago Pastorino : https://hackmd.io/Br1k5qy0QWuPdbMZMdyeqQ ?
yes
so that’s a good point
of course we can always do better
we maybe should have started this meeting by looking at that doc.
like splitting actual tasks and having people assigned and all that in my opinion is useful

Yeah, I think in order to have a successful week, we need both a goal and a set of concrete steps to take to achieve it. I felt like it wasn't until the second day that I had something concrete to work on trying.
namely: which things on that doc were actually investigated, and which things could be potential future efforts
we could even spend the first day of the sprint working on tasking
(actually that doc is probably too big to review in this meeting, at least at this point in ths meeting. :lol: )
So, how can we best ensure better planning in future sprints?
I also kind of wonder if a week is too short. By the time I felt like I was making progress, the week was nearly over.
yes that’s true too. Its possible that a two week long sprint would be better. But its also a bigger ask.

pnkfelix said:

So, how can we best ensure better planning in future sprints?

I guess we could try to open some github issues or have some tasks, things written in a way that is ready for someone to read it and start to investigate
I’m going to start writing down concrete things at end of https://hackmd.io/n_G11TzET1CjaTeouQ6CsQ?both
so far I’ve got (summary): make it longer, and better planning
I think having a kickoff meeting day 1 either on Zulip or video chat would have helped.
The first day felt especially messy to me.
I feel the same
couldn't have made things better if we had got together to plan briefly on the first day?
yeah I debate about that
sorry, I may be the let's plan kind of person :joy:
with a week long sprint, it seems … not great to spend a whole day on planning
but of course without planning, the whole week is potentially wasted
not necessary a day, maybe one hour or 20 minutes, whatever
right
probably the right thing
is to at least set up the set aside time to plan
like, in my ideal world, I was hoping we’d have enough ideas written down that we’d just run with them
without needing coordination
I think we need to set up more time to do pre-planning as well. I'm not sure how to make that happen though.
but that’s not realistic
(its certianly not realistic for broader efforts. I was hoping that memshrink wouldn’t need much coordination.)
if pre-planning is possible is great, but if it's not possible I guess some time of the sprint could be used for that purpose
but saying “we’re going to ensure there’s a kickoff at the start, and part of that is to have time set aside for planning the week"
and then deciding in a Just-in-Time fashion “okay, do the plans we have look good enough? Then lets run with them"
that seems right to me
right
Perhaps we need "deliverables" due before the sprint. For example, we need to have x work items identified 1 week before the sprint.
it's interesting
One other thing
at some point, if we have n sprint topics as candidates we could choose the one that have more clear goals or deliverables
on this sprint, we explicitly said “we don’t think we have mentorship capacity to onboard new vounteers"
I want to get thoughts on that going forward
i.e. a sprint seems like an ideal time to try to drum up excitement/involvement
but it does mean we need mentorship capacity
yes, that's definitely the upside
(maybe some way of splitting time up? “mentorship mornings” …)
wonder if people able to mentor have capacity during a sprint
another approach
would be to have some sprints just dedicated to mentorship
I dunno
I think the dedicated ones would probably work best, as I wouldn
I think in retrospect we made the right call for this sprint. I know I personally didn't have time to mentor people and I'm not sure this would have been the best topic for someone new anyway.
't want to focus on the same topics
another question is ... does it worth mixing these two things in one effort?, I meant, maybe mentorship should be done in a different initiative or something
so maybe we can have mentorship sprints
where we pick topics that we know are good mentorship items?

Santiago Pastorino said:

another question is ... does it worth mixing these two things in one effort?, I meant, maybe mentorship should be done in a different initiative or something

as in, a sprint isn’t even the right structure for mentorship?
that’s likely true as well
I think having a "sprint" dedicated to mentoring people is really interesting. It reminds me a lot of the "Impl" days we had years ago which helped me get a lot more involved.
right, that was largely what I was thinking of
Okay we’re at the hour

Wesley Wiser said:

I think in retrospect we made the right call for this sprint. I know I personally didn't have time to mentor people and I'm not sure this would have been the best topic for someone new anyway.

Since I'm somewhat new to the compiler, I might have a few words on this. It was nice working on something with Wesley that we were both not experts in. I felt like I could contribute a bit, but I still learned a ton about the compiler and Windows

pnkfelix said:

Santiago Pastorino said:

another question is ... does it worth mixing these two things in one effort?, I meant, maybe mentorship should be done in a different initiative or something

as in, a sprint isn’t even the right structure for mentorship?

I was saying that trying to persue important things for the compiler and having mentoring mixed there may not be the best, but I'm not sure because I'm probably not in a position to mentor :)
That being said, I didn't do a full week's worth of sprinting
having a dedicated sprint for mentorship may right be a good idea

But my opinion is that we really need concrete items to help new people work on and drive to completion. I'm not sure it feels great to be mentored on something that never really pans out or gets merged.
I was mentioning mainly that I'd split things, don't like that much multi purpose things :)
That is true. Assigning mentors unimportant things is lower risk, but it is not as welcoming
but there’s plenty of important stuff
that could be handed out during a mentorship oriented sprint
Even a P-high bug-fixing oriented sprint
could be interesting for that

pnkfelix said:

Okay we’re at the hour

I do want to respect peoples’ time
BTW some things that are somewhat unimportant can feel important when you're new. It's a bit of an art, but I think there's a good balance that be struck there
So I’m going to say this meeting, as a formal thing, is over. But we can keep the conversation going asynchronouly in this topic, I think.
thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending! Sorry again for being late.

We should have a label for PRs opened as part of the effort. I'm trying to look at PRs closed recently to see what panned out and what didn't and it's difficult to sift through the PR list to find related things.

Wesley Wiser said:

We should have a label for PRs opened as part of the effort. I'm trying to look at PRs closed recently to see what panned out and what didn't and it's difficult to sift through the PR list to find related things.

label: sprint-memshrink ?
or maybe you’re talking just about future sprints
Uh both
I guess this is more of a "let's do this different next time" comment.

In case anyone is interested, I've tried to compile a list of PRs that I believe were related to the sprint. It's very possible I missed including some or included some that were not actually related. https://hackmd.io/3KceGInfQRi-10CrbNGJUg

pnkfelix said:

hey nikomatsakis , do you know if your perf-focus tool is still of use?

got distracted, @pnkfelix, but I haven't tried it in a while -- I imagine it still mostly works, or could be made to work with some tweaking

Wesley Wiser said:

We should have a label for PRs opened as part of the effort. I'm trying to look at PRs closed recently to see what panned out and what didn't and it's difficult to sift through the PR list to find related things.

I use this query to search for perf related PRs, that could help to filter them a bit at least: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pulls?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Apr+sort%3Aupdated-desc++rust-timer
